issues.text: the question of the constitutional validity of the Jammu and Kashmir Agrarian Reforms Act, 1972 (Act of XXXVI of 1972), briefly called the Act, and the rules framed thereunder

anchor.surface_text: raises the question of the constitutional validity of the Jammu and Kashmir Agrarian Reforms Act, 1972 (Act of XXXVI of 1972), briefly called the Act, and the rules f

issues.text: The short question that arises for consideration is whether the Act is protected under Article 31A of the Constitution as applicable to the State of Jammu and Kashmir providing, as claimed by the State, for a scheme of agrarian reforms

anchor.surface_text: The short question that arises for consideration is whether the Act is protected under Article 31A of the Constitution as applicable to the State of Jammu and Kashmir providing, as claimed by the State, for a scheme of agrarian reforms. If the answer is in the affirmative, all objections under Articles 14, 19 and 31 would be of no avail.

issues.text: whether the impugned legislation can come under the canopy of protection of Article 31A of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: We may now, therefore, turn to the Act to determine whether the impugned legislation can come under the canopy of protection of Article 31A of the Constitution. The Act itself carries the appellation Agrarian Reforms Act These words, themselves, may not be decisive in the absence of provisions in the Act disclosing a genuine

issues.text: whether the Act is not saved by the provisions of Article 31A of the Constitution as applicable to the State of Jammu and Kashmir since it is not a piece of legislation bearing on agrarian reform

anchor.surface_text: By taking an additional ground, they also aver that the Act is not saved by the provisions of Article 31A of the Constitution as applicable to the State of Jammu and Kashmir since it is not a piece of legislation bearing on agrarian reform.

issues.text: whether exclusion of an orchard from the definition of land under section 2(4) of the Act is motivated and designed in the interests of highly placed influential persons in the State who own such orchards

anchor.surface_text: They also allege that exclusion of an orchard from the definition of land under section 2(4) of the Act is motivated and designed in the interests of highly placed influential persons in the State who own such orchards.

issues.text: whether there is any discrimination in favour of the orchard-owners in not including land which was an orchard on the first day of September, 1971 within the definition of land under the Act

anchor.surface_text: We do not see any justification for the comment, adverted to above, that there is any discrimination in favour of the orchard-owners in not including land which was an orchard on the first day of September, 1971 within the definition of land under the Act since orchard is reckoned along with the land for the purpose of determination of the ceiling area under the Act.

issues.text: whether the amount intended to be paid as compensation is illusory and the Act is, therefore, of a confiscatory nature

anchor.surface_text: their grievance is that by the impugned Act they along with a large number of similar land-owners have been rendered landless. They further allege that the amount intended to be paid as compensation is illusory and the Act is, therefore, of a confiscatory nature.

issues.text: whether the Act can be successfully challenged on the score of violation of Article 14, Article 19 and Article 31

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the impugned Act has been passed with the definite object of agrarian reforms and cannot be successfully challenged on the score of violation of Article 14, Article 19 and Article 31 in view of the provisions of Article 31A.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the impugned Act has been passed with the definite object of agrarian reforms and cannot be successfully challenged on the score of violation of Article 14, Article 19 and Article 31

holdings.text: the impugned Act has been passed with the definite object of agrarian reforms and cannot be successfully challenged on the score of violation of Article 14, Article 19 and Article 31 in view of the provisions of Article 31A

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the impugned Act has been passed with the definite object of agrarian reforms and cannot be successfully challenged on the score of violation of Article 14, Article 19 and Article 31 in view of the provisions of Article 31A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examined title, preamble, definitions (land, orchard, personal cultivation, ceiling), ss.3-4 (vesting non-personal/excess land in State), ss.5,7-8 (vesting in tillers, resumption incentives), s.10 (disposal surplus), s.25 (orchard tax), s.51 (prior laws), overall scheme distributes land to tillers subject to ceiling, building on prior reforms

holdings.text: From a review of the foregoing provisions it is obvious that the Act contains a clear programme of agrarian reforms

anchor.surface_text: From a review of the foregoing provisions it is obvious that the Act contains a clear programme of agrarian reforms in taking stock of the land in the State which is not in personal cultivation (section 3) and which though in personal cultivation is in excess

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions disclose genuine scheme via vesting excess/non-personal land, ceiling on land/orchards, focus on personal cultivation as defined in s.2(7), disposal to tillers, prior inconsistent laws cease per s.51

holdings.text: We do not see any justification for the comment, adverted to above, that there is any discrimination in favour of the orchard-owners in not including land which was an orchard on the first day of September, 1971 within the definition of land under the Act since orchard is reckoned along with the land for the purpose of determination of the ceiling area under the Act

anchor.surface_text: We do not see any justification for the comment, adverted to above, that there is any discrimination in favour of the orchard-owners in not including land which was an orchard on the first day of September, 1971 within the definition of land under the Act since orchard is reckoned along with the land for the purpose of determination of the ceiling area under the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Orchards counted toward ceiling area s.2(2); excess orchards taxed annually s.25; exclusion per s.2(4) justified by definition, nexus to agriculture/pasture, special significance in J&K (judicial notice), prior law treatment

holdings.text: No motive can be attributed to the legislature in the choice of legislation within its constitutional competence

anchor.surface_text: No motive can be attributed to the legislature in the choice of legislation within its constitutional competence. We, therefore, do not find any merit whatsoever in the objection on the score of motive, or that there is any unreasonable discrimination in favour of the orchard-owners as such.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General principle: courts do not inquire into legislative motive if act within competence; applied to reject claims of oblique motive in orchard exclusion and overall enactment

anchor.surface_text: We do not see any justification for the comment, adverted to above, that there is any discrimination in favour of the orchard-owners in not including land which was an orchard on the first day of September, 1971 within the definition of land under the Act since orchard is reckoned along with the land for the purpose of determination of the ceiling area under the Act.
The application, therefore, fails and is dismissed.
